content.text: Solutions A and B consisting of calcium hydroxide dissolved in water. <image 1> Solution A is a calcium hydroxide solution that has a concentration of 0.350 M and a volume of 500. mL. What mass of calcium hydroxide was dissolved to make this solution? (Note: The molar mass of calcium hydroxide is 74.093 g/mol.)

To find the mass of calcium hydroxide dissolved in Solution A, we can use the formula:

\[ \text{Mass} = \text{Molarity} \times \text{Volume} \times \text{Molar Mass} \]

Given:
- Molarity (\(M\)) = 0.350 M
- Volume (\(V\)) = 500 mL = 0.500 L (since 1 L = 1000 mL)
- Molar Mass (\(MM\)) = 74.093 g/mol

Plugging these values into the formula:

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.350 \, \text{M} \times 0.500 \, \text{L} \times 74.093 \, \text{g/mol} \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.350 \times 0.500 \times 74.093 \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.175 \times 74.093 \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 12.96 \, \text{g} \]

Therefore, the mass of calcium hydroxide dissolved in Solution A is 12.96 grams.

final_answer:
To find the mass of calcium hydroxide dissolved in Solution A, we can use the formula:

\[ \text{Mass} = \text{Molarity} \times \text{Volume} \times \text{Molar Mass} \]

Given:
- Molarity (\(M\)) = 0.350 M
- Volume (\(V\)) = 500 mL = 0.500 L (since 1 L = 1000 mL)
- Molar Mass (\(MM\)) = 74.093 g/mol

Plugging these values into the formula:

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.350 \, \text{M} \times 0.500 \, \text{L} \times 74.093 \, \text{g/mol} \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.350 \times 0.500 \times 74.093 \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.175 \times 74.093 \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 12.96 \, \text{g} \]

Therefore, the mass of calcium hydroxide dissolved in Solution A is 12.96 grams.
